chapter.title: Operating &ceph; Services
chapter.para: &ceph; related services are operated with the systemctl command. The operation takes place on the node you are currently logged in to. You need to have &rootuser; privileges to be able to operate on &ceph; services.
The following subcommands affect all &ceph; services on a given node:

listitem.para: Prints the status information of the service(s) specified by target.
Starts the service(s) specified by target if they are not already running.
Stops the running service(s) specified by target.
Enables the service(s) specified by target so that they are automatically started on system start-up.
Disables the service(s) specified by target so that they are not automatically started on system start-up. You need to start them manually with systemctl start.

chapter.para: The following subcommand is supported for OSD related targets:

listitem.para: Prevents the service from being started manually or automatically. systemctl is creating a symbolic link from the specific target file located in /etc/systemd/system/ to /dev/null. Targets in /etc/systemd override those provided by packages in /usr/lib/systemd. &systemd; recognizes the symbolic link and will not start the service.
Opposite to systemctl mask. Removes the symbolic link from the specific target file located in /etc/systemd/system/ to /dev/null, so that targets located in /usr/lib/systemd are valid again.

chapter.para: You can either operate on all &ceph; services at once, or all &ceph; services of a certain type (such as OSD or monitor), or a specific instance of service identified by its instance name.

sect1.title: Operating on All &ceph; Services
sect1.para: To operate on all &ceph; services at once, run:
